awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Advancing Multi-Hazard Assessment and Risk-Based Design for Offshore Wind Energy Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Offshore wind energy is a resource of renewable energy that is conveniently accessible to many major population centers, but harvesting offshore wind energy currently costs more than traditional sources.  The research goal of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant is to advance knowledge that can lead to reduction in the cost of offshore wind energy through (1) a much sharper understanding and modeling of the spatio-temporal interaction of multiple offshore hazards that impact the system-level performance of offshore wind energy farms to reduce insurance and financing costs, (2) the calculation of novel system-level performance metrics, and (3) the advancement of shallow water wave modeling to mitigate the current reliance on overly conservative design methods.  The educational goals of this project are to leverage field experiences at state-of-the-art offshore wind-themed sites in New England to inspire high school students to pursue science, engineering, mathematics, and technology careers and to transfer knowledge of multi-hazard assessment and design to the public, other researchers, and the practicing engineering community.

This project will achieve the research goal through fundamental advancements to metamodels (surrogate models) to overcome restrictions that have previously limited the impact of such models in the context of multi-hazard assessment of spatially-distributed infrastructure. Specifically, novel metamodels will be developed to include several important features, such as spatio-temporally varying hazards, high-dimensionality of the input and output vectors, explicit accounting of model adequacy by quantifying inter- and intra-event uncertainty in the model predictions compared to measurements, and a coupling of multi-hazard and system/structural metamodels. The research will also explore innovative models that overcome important deficiencies in the modeling of nonlinear, highly skewed shallow water waves and their associated hydrodynamic loads, including breaking waves. The research will synthesize these advances and generate system-level performance metrics that will provide a fundamentally different paradigm for designing offshore wind farms. The project will leverage partnerships with state, city, academic, and industry organizations.  The research outcomes are expected to have broad impact beyond the offshore wind industry, given the national needs in multi-hazard analysis and infrastructure system resilience, and the potential of metamodeling applications in civil engineering and other fields.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. targets having 30 GW of offshore wind energy capacity by 2030. A better understanding of the risk of damage to offshore wind infrastructure exposed to extreme metocean events, like hurricanes, is needed to accelerate development. This research project included model development, numerical simulations, and large-scale experiments designed to increase understanding of the spatio-temporal interaction of multiple metocean hazards, along with their associated loading of support structures of offshore wind turbines, to advance the ability of engineers, developers and regulators to assess risk of structural damage. The project was organized into two research initiatives and two educational initiatives The two research initiatives are to (1) overcome existing limitations of surrogate models for multiple hazards both generally and specifically as they apply to extreme offshore conditions, including important spatial and temporal variations and (2) conceive and implement system-level performance metrics for offshore wind farms subjected to multiple hazards and overcome deficiencies in design methods for shallow water waves to include important nonlinear features such as breaking waves. The two educational initiatives are to (1) inspire high school students to pursue STEM-related careers by collaborating with the Massachusetts Clean Energy Center, the Northeastern University Center for STEM, graduate students and local schools to organize a series of offshore wind-related field experiences and demonstrations at several offshore wind-themed sites in New England and (2) transfer knowledge of multi-hazard assessment and design to the public, other researchers and the practicing engineering community.

The project generated several research outcomes, each of which was published in a journal paper.

  • Temporal characteristics were analyzed for hurricane-induced wind, wave and storm surge along the U.S. Atlantic coast to assess the degree of inaccuracy of assuming maxima are simultaneous, a common engineering assumption. A simplified approach was demonstrated to have suitable accuracy.
  • A new method for generating environmental contours of multiple metocean conditions was created and shown to overcome several limitations of traditional approaches, while increasing accuracy.
  • A novel probabilistic model was created to provide accurate probability estimation for both frequently occurring and extreme values of datasets with temporal correlation, an improvement to the traditional method of modeling the frequently occurring and extreme values separately.
  • A detailed assessment of Deep Learning Algorithms showed that they have extraordinary potential for acting as a metamodel to predict time histories of time-dependent hurricane-induced metocean hazards. The algorithms, which have the capacity to approximate nonlinear processes and can be optimized to fully utilize large training dataset, had a ~90% reduction in terms of prediction errors compared a more conventional approach.
  • Contribution to an international exercise to benchmark methods for generating environmental contours. The benchmarking exercise showed how different joint distribution models and different contour construction methods lead to significant differences in the resulting contours.
  • The creation of a breaking wave hazard model to examine the influence of breaking wave criteria including effects of wave height, wave steepness and seafloor bathymetry. Environmental contours of wave height and period, calculated using a catalog of synthetic hurricanes, were used to create maps of the mean return period of breaking conditions across the U.S. Atlantic coast.

The project also generated an experimental dataset from a month-long series of experiments executed at the NHERI Large Wave Flume facility at Oregon State University. This dataset provides fundamental statistical information to characterize the wave and loading random processes for linear and nonlinear waves, including breaking waves. The data was used in this project to create idealizations suitable for practice of the wave random process and the hydrodynamic loading on structures.

High school outreach efforts and undergraduate research experiences provided educational and workforce training for many students. A desktop turbine was designed and fabricated for outreach events intended to demonstrate the physics of wind turbines. Three PhD students were educated using funding from this project.

 


Last Modified: 06/14/2022
Modified by: Andrew T Myers
